Key Arguments: The legislation inhibits freedom of speech, which is essential for democracy and scientific progress.
Existing laws already address harm, incitement, discrimination, defamation, and libel, making new laws unnecessary.
Truth or falseness is subjective and can change over time, making it problematic to legislate against misinformation.
The legislation risks empowering the interests of the powerful over the less powerful.
Historical examples, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, show that government-imposed opinions can be false and harmful.
The removal of the privilege against self-incrimination is concerning and reminiscent of historical abuses.
Notable Quotes: Freedom to speak is a foundation for the processes of democracy and science.
We have no need for laws against misinformation or disinformation, because we already have laws against causing harm, inciting violence, discrimination, defamation, and libel.
Many opinions once imposed by those in authority have turned out in hindsight to be false.
This exposure draft carries proposed legislation for enhancing the power of government to censor opinion.
